# Superscripts and Subscripts

This article demonstrates superscript and subscript elements used for footnotes, citations, and scientific notation. These should be preserved as inline HTML.

Einstein's famous equation is E = mc<sup>2</sup>, which relates energy and mass.

Water's chemical formula is H<sub>2</sub>O, consisting of hydrogen and oxygen atoms.

This claim requires a citation<sup><a href="#ref1">[1]</a></sup> and another reference<sup><a href="#ref2">[2]</a></sup> for completeness.

In mathematics, we write x<sup>n</sup> + y<sup>n</sup> = z<sup>n</sup> for Fermat's Last Theorem, and a<sub>0</sub> + a<sub>1</sub>x + a<sub>2</sub>x<sup>2</sup> for polynomial expressions.

Carbon dioxide (CO<sub>2</sub>) levels have risen significantly. The 1<sup>st</sup>, 2<sup>nd</sup>, and 3<sup>rd</sup> measurements confirmed this trend.

## References

1.  First reference source
2.  Second reference source
